title: Mastering Verb Tenses: The Path to American English Fluency
subtitle: Unit 1: Hello, America!
objectives: Identify and distinguish between all major verb tenses in American English.
Correctly conjugate verbs in simple, continuous, perfect, and perfect continuous tenses.
Apply appropriate verb tenses in different contexts to express accurate time frames.
Recognize common errors in tense usage and learn how to avoid them.
Enhance fluency and confidence in speaking and writing.

vocabulary.definition: A form of a verb that shows when an action happens
vocabulary.example: The verb tense tells us if the action is in the past, present, or future.

vocabulary.definition: To change a verb form according to tense, person, or number
vocabulary.example: You need to conjugate the verb 'to be' correctly: I am, you are, he is.

vocabulary.definition: A tense used for habits, facts, and general truths
vocabulary.example: I work every day. The sun rises in the east.

vocabulary.definition: A tense used for actions happening right now
vocabulary.example: I am working on my homework right now.

vocabulary.definition: A tense connecting past actions to the present
vocabulary.example: I have worked here for five years.

vocabulary.definition: A tense used for completed actions in the past
A tense used for actions that will happen
The length of time something continues
vocabulary.example: The duration of the meeting was two hours.

exercises.question: Which tense is used for actions happening right now?
exercises.explanation: Present Continuous is used for actions happening at the moment of speaking.

exercises.question: She ___ (write) emails every day.
exercises.explanation: Simple Present is used for habitual actions. Third person singular adds 's'.

exercises.question: I ___ (work) on this project since Monday.
exercises.explanation: Present Perfect Continuous is used for actions that started in the past and continue to the present.

exercises.question: Which sentence uses the Past Perfect correctly?
options: I had finished my homework before dinner.
I have finished my homework before dinner.
I finished my homework before dinner.
I was finishing my homework before dinner.
exercises.explanation: Past Perfect (had + past participle) is used for an action completed before another past action.

exercises.question: Describe your daily routine using at least three different verb tenses.
exercises.sampleAnswer: Every morning, I wake up at 7 AM (Simple Present). Right now, I am learning English (Present Continuous). By next year, I will have improved my skills significantly (Future Perfect).
